Article.ArticleTitle: Effects of O<sub>3</sub> on alder photosynthesis and symbiosis with Frankia.

AbstractText: Alnus serrulata (Aiton) Willdenow seedlings with and without root nodules formed by the nitrogen-fixing actinomycete Frankia were exposed to clean filtered air or ozone (O<sub>3</sub> ) at 0.12 μl l<sup>-1</sup> for 27 d (approximately 164 h total exposure). Gas exchange measurements on leaves and transmission electron micrographs of root nodule cells were made to detect any O<sub>3</sub> effects on the functioning of leaves and the root symbiont. Photosynthesis, stomatal conductance, and internal CO<sub>2</sub> , concentration were calculated for all plants in clean O<sub>3</sub> -free air more than three weeks after the fumigations began. Significant positive correlations between photosynthesis and conductance were found for leaves of control nodulated and unnodulated alders and O<sub>3</sub> -treated nodulated alders. There was a weak positive correlation between photosynthesis and conductance for unnodulated O<sub>3</sub> -treated seedlings measured in clean air. When O<sub>3</sub> -treated leaves were measured during fumigation with O<sub>3</sub> , no positive correlation between photosynthesis and conductance was found for either nodulated or unnodulated seedlings. Photosynthetic rates of leaves having the highest stomatal conductance values were decreased by O<sub>3</sub> for both nodulated and unnodulated plants. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) revealed that after a 27 d exposure of shoots to O<sub>3</sub> , host root cells of nodules from O<sub>3</sub> -treated plants lacked organelles and showed extensive cytoplasmic breakdown. Hyphae and N<sub>2</sub> -fixing vesicles of Frankia appeared normal. The Frankia endophyte seems to be more resistant to O<sub>3</sub> than is the host root nodule cell. These results show that ambient levels of O<sub>3</sub> may reduce photosynthesis and bring about associated degradation in rhizosphere symbiosis.
